title: Market Sensing Using a Graph Database

author: Amar Shan, YarcData
category: Top->Computer Science->Semantic Web->RDF - Resource Description Framework

segmentation: So I'm more from York data, which is part of Cray and I'm here to talk to you today, but.
Market sensing using a graph database.
Let's talk for a second about what market sensing really is.
Consider this example here of what happened on September, the September 29th at 2:19 PM.

The Wall Street Journal published an article saying that Eastman Kodak Company was going to his contract ING Jones Day offer, restructuring advice about 5 minutes later, 224 the stock was off by 28% and by the end of the day it was off by 54%.
What this shows is the ability of news to move markets right and market sensing is the refers to taking information from a lot of different sources.
Taking information from news sources as well as as market data and combining it all to come up with an assessment of what's going to happen to the stock going forward.
Obviously each stocks don't trade in a vacuum.
You know if a company company that produces hard drives in Thailand experiences flood, that's going to have a downstream impact on companies that use those components.

So basically what that points to is that market sensing is a large scale graph analytics problem where you really need to understand the dependencies between all of the different news indicators and all of the different companies that are being traded.
Now.
If you can do that, there is money to be made, but let's.
Talk about the challenges in order to get there, OK?
So the first thing is current this is.
As you can imagine, this is this involves very large datasets dealing with large data.

Big Data is based currently on searching, searching and this is often described as searching for a needle in a haystack, and we know what you know when you're looking for a needle in a haystack, you know what you're looking for and you can break up the problem into lots of little bales of hay and look for the needle in all of them.
But the problem with market sensing is that we don't know what we're looking for, right?
We have all this data that's coming together.
We the patterns that we're looking for are constantly changing.
We can't break the problem up and.

To quote Gardner, when the purpose of the system is to discover new relationships as opposed to extracting information from already known relationships, it's very hard to achieve performance, and it's impossible to partition the data across multiple computers.
And as I showed you in the previous example, being able to do this in a timely fashion means money.
So let's talk about what?

The process of discovery looks like when you're using market sensing, so the discovery begins by taking to get by bringing in all of the different sources of data, load the data from all of the different sources, then what you do is you hypothesize.
Use it using the partial information what the theory that you think will lead to valuable predictions.
You test that theory against existing knowledge or data, and if it proves out then you act on it.
You trade on it and then the cycle continues to add in new source of data you produce new hypothesis and and so it goes.

So the value of being able to to be able to produce data to be able to being able to execute this very quickly is that in the time it takes to validate one hypothesis, you can now validate 1000 hypothesis and that mean.
Money to make this all possible.
York data is brought it graph analytic appliance to the market, which Kombucha sensually provides.
A Native graph database.

It consist contains up to 512 terabytes of memory, and it's got a custom graph processor which allows you to do this kind of this kind of knowledge discovery application between three and five orders of magnitude faster than you could do it with any other technology.
Let's go back to market sensing what we for the purpose of this illustration.
What we what we did was we brought in data from a variety of different sources sources.
We computed all of these different indicators, everything from whether contracts have been won or loss to add weather weather adverted prominent hedge funds are buying and selling etc.
Over 100 indicators and constantly growing.
And from that we.
Built what we called a bicep indicator which is really just an indicator of where this talk is headed up or down.
I only have time for one example but you can see the red bar shows you the bicep indicator associated with events of September 29th.
You can see that it's it's very very strongly correlated to a negative move in the stock.
As it turned out, but it turns out with bicep indicator it actually turns to give us a very strong positive and negative correlation when there's big changes in the marketplace.
So just to wrap up.
What we've shown is essentially at an appliance that allows you to gain business insights by discovering these unknown relationships, and to do it at scale in real time.
And all that's really all about making it possible to, in the case of market moving, find these relationships in a timely fashion.
Thank you.
